title: How does CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) work?
content: Explain the mechanism of a CSRF attack and its potential impact.
sampleAnswers: CSRF tricks an authenticated user into unknowingly performing actions on a web application, like changing account details or transferring funds, by submitting malicious requests from another site.

title: How can you prevent CSRF attacks?

options.text: Use CSRF tokens in forms
Use SameSite cookie attribute
Use HTTPS
Disable cookies completely

explanation: CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies, and HTTPS help prevent CSRF attacks. Disabling cookies is not practical for most web apps.

title: What is the difference between DOM-based XSS and Stored XSS?

options.text: DOM-based XSS executes purely on the client side
Stored XSS persists in a database or storage and affects multiple users
DOM-based XSS stores payloads on the server
Stored XSS only affects a single user

explanation: DOM-based XSS runs in the browser, while Stored XSS is saved in server-side storage and executed when other users access it.

title: Why should you avoid using inline scripts in your frontend code?
content: Explain the security risk associated with inline JavaScript.
sampleAnswers: Inline scripts can easily be exploited by attackers in XSS attacks. Using external scripts and event bindings reduces the risk of executing malicious code.

title: What is the role of Content Security Policy (CSP) in frontend security?

options.text: Restricts sources of scripts and other resources
Helps prevent XSS attacks
Replaces the need for input validation
Can block inline styles and scripts if configured

explanation: CSP controls resource loading and helps prevent XSS, but does not replace input validation.

title: Why is sanitizing user input important in frontend security?
content: Explain the consequences of unsanitized inputs.
sampleAnswers: Unsanitized input can contain scripts or HTML that execute in the user's browser, leading to XSS attacks, data theft, or session hijacking.

title: How does the SameSite cookie attribute improve security?

options.text: Prevents cookies from being sent with cross-site requests by default
Mitigates CSRF attacks
Encrypts cookie contents
Prevents cookies from being accessed via JavaScript

explanation: SameSite restricts cross-site sending of cookies to reduce CSRF risks. It does not encrypt cookies or make them HttpOnly.

title: What are best practices for secure cookie usage in frontend applications?

options.text: Use HttpOnly to prevent JavaScript access
Use Secure flag to enforce HTTPS transmission
Avoid storing sensitive tokens in localStorage
Use SameSite attribute to mitigate CSRF

explanation: HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite attributes protect cookies from XSS and CSRF attacks. Sensitive tokens should not be stored in localStorage.

title: What is the risk of using eval() in frontend JavaScript?
content: Explain why eval() can be dangerous in web applications.
sampleAnswers: eval() executes arbitrary strings as code, which can lead to remote code execution if user input is passed, making applications vulnerable to XSS and other attacks.

title: How do you mitigate XSS in React applications?

options.text: Use JSX curly braces to escape content
Sanitize any user-generated HTML before using dangerouslySetInnerHTML
Use external scripts instead of inline scripts
Store session tokens in localStorage without encryption

explanation: React automatically escapes content in JSX. Any HTML inserted via dangerouslySetInnerHTML must be sanitized. Avoid storing sensitive tokens insecurely.
